It should also be noted that the struggle against formal subsumption is one thing, but the struggle against real subsumption, which is much more difficult from the laborers’ standpoint, is another.
Note that this backward form of capitalism is not the same as what Lenin refers to when he defines imperialism as “moribund capitalism,” which is “capitalism in transition” (1939: 126).

Still another response is what can be called political accumulation. Landowners formally subsuming labor utilize local state institutions including police to beat up striking laborers, or to have them jailed on false charges. Surplus from agriculture is used to support political parties and bribe state bureaucracy which, in turn, helps capital’s use of the state’s rural development resources illegally, in a form of primitive accumulation (Wilson 1999). The fact of state intervention and the fact of it being instrumentally used by local dominant classes suggest that reproduction of (agrarian) capitalism is a deeply political matter (Harriss 1992).

Owners often prefer to hire women to men to just pre-empt the possibility of men going on a strike. I have come across this in my research on floriculture in Karnataka, where women laborers are seen as less difficult and willing to work for less. To the extent that patriarchy can be used to divide the working class, the impetus for technological change may be less strong.
It should also be noted that by taking up work refused by men, women enabled men to prolong their strike. Other studies may reveal the long-term impact of this on technological change.

This is a particularly notable tendency under neoliberalism; in spite of the availability of local labor, employers tend to use migrant labor in order to exercise maximum control over it, avoid any possible labor conflict, and squeeze out the maximum amount of surplus value by paying low wages.

The value of labor power must be seen as geographically differentiated, rather than as a constant within a country. If, for example, traditional needs of tribal migrants are more limited, they can work for less and in a more disciplined manner, and thus help their owners make an above-average profit.

The use of attached labor does not automatically suggest that there is a feudal mode of production. Where landowners producing a commodity for profit find it economically profitable and politically useful to hire attached laborers, they do.

It should be noted that rental extraction, stressed in the semi-feudal thesis, has been decreasing in importance in all provinces; at the all India level, the operated area leased-in declined from 20.6 percent in 1953-54 to 10.6 percent in 1971-72 to 6.5 percent in 2002-03 (Bhalla 2007: 31-31). Of course, these figures, to some extent, underestimate tenancy because some of this is not reported.

To the extent that the dominant form of surplus appropriated by money-lenders is in the form of usurious interest, they are not capitalist (in productive form). Similarly, to the extent that the dominant form of surplus appropriated by landowners is in the form of rent, they are also not capitalists. It is important to note, however, that a given person can appropriate surplus in multiple forms such as usurious interest, ground rent, and profit from production.
Here I refer to the fact that landowners are investing money to make more money (a process not to be confused with conspicuous consumption).

In 1999-2000, one rural person needed 19 rupees a day to be able to buy enough food to give her the minimum calories needed (i.e. 2,400) (Patnaik 2007: 141). If the daily wage is 60-70 rupees now, one can imagine how far the wage is below the cost of reproduction of a family of five members.
The degree of caste oppression has come down. Upper-caste landowners would not easily hurt the sentiments of low-caste laborers.
In a sense, direct producers engaged in commodity production receive a part of the means of production (land) as an advance from property owners.

One may ask: why, when confronted with increasing wage-hikes, landowners in the study area did not go in for mechanization, whereas many farmers in Punjab and Haryana would have done so. One reason is that landowners in the study area are small owners: less than 10 percent of them own more than 5 acres, whereas in Punjab and Haryana 25.3 percent of owners own more than 5 acres (Sharma 1992). Also, with the neoliberal economic policy in force since 1991, the prices of inputs such as fertilizers have been increasing much faster, because of withdrawal of government subsidies, than the price of paddy, the dominant crop in the area. Thus farming based on directly hiring labor, with rising wage costs, has been unviable for smaller landowners; given the amount of means of production (land) in their hands, the amount of surplus value available to them is not adequate for investment in machines. This means that, as explained earlier, the effect of class struggle on accumulation will depend on local, contextual factors, including the degree of concentration in means of production.
Note that most of the work is still done by hand, and that only ploughing is done by tractors.

Formal subsumption is dominant not just empirically. It is also dominant in terms of the logic of the system in India as in most other less developed country contexts: property owners producing for the market using hired labor not able to cut costs can go out of business.

Capital also makes use of labor whose reproduction is only partly borne by the capitalist wage system; this happens when, for example, laboring households working seasonally for capital as migrant laborers may collect some means of subsistence (fuel, etc.) from common properties for free and/or who may own some means of production/subsistence.
This cannot be fully captured through data at the provincial scale but must be investigated at smaller scales (villages, clusters of villages, etc.)

This approach to uneven development is different from one (employed by Harvey, Smith, etc.) in which it is assumed that capitalism is advanced capitalism, and that uneven development is spatial unevenness in the location of productive forces, caused by a tension between mobility and immobility of capital.

The Third World, especially its rural areas, is less developed not because it is not dominantly capitalist. It is rather less developed in spite of being capitalist. It is capitalist not in the sense of exchange relations, but capitalist in the sphere of production. And, it is less developed not just because of the much talked about surplus transfer but also because of the nature of its capitalism, the capitalism based on formal subsumption of labor.

This is not to deny that there are localities where pre-capitalist relations exist, where land and labor are not commodities, and where extra-economic coercion is exercised in the sphere of production, to which the caste system contributes. But these local relations do not define the system’s dynamics, although they affect how the law of value in the system actually works in specific places.

Another implication of the argument of the paper for radical development theory is also that agrarian transition, and indeed development itself, must be seen as multiple transitions: from pre-capitalist relations (and hybrid subsumption) to formal subsumption of labor under capital, from formal to real subsumption of labor (which is the focus of the paper), and finally from the latter to cooperative labor. Radical development research, much of which is obsessed with the barriers to development under capitalism, must investigate the conditions under the regimes of formal and real subsumption that facilitate/inhibit the emergence of the working class and poor peasants as a force to challenge capitalist subsumption of labor, along with any remnants of pre-capitalist social relations.

Among constraints on the state is the (relative) lack of state funds due to the overall lower development of productive forces, and ruling classes being reluctant to share a part of the surplus value as taxes. Also, under neoliberalism, through its pressure on the state, the alliance of imperialist capital and domestic capital politically inhibits the enhancement of the social wage and other pro-labor interventions, which could potentially enhance the bargaining power of labor and consequently force capital to develop productive forces through technological change.

Further, given the transfer of resources in the form of debt-payment, etc., from these societies in the system of imperialism, the resources necessary to invest in technology may be limited, although this is not to say that imperialism completely rules out technological change in the Third World. Indeed, imperialism is partly responsible for “combined and uneven development.” The green revolution technology was indeed promoted in part by imperialism. The sale of modern farm inputs including tractors by the United States in India was a strategy to counter the crisis of overproduction in the United States (Cleaver 1972). More recently, the introduction of green-house farming in floriculture (at least initially) and contract farming under neoliberalism have also happened partly through the involvement of imperialist companies. To the extent that technological change in Third World agriculture will create a market for products for these companies and/or will increase relative surplus value, a part of which will be shared by imperialist countries, imperialism may not be inimical to technological change.
That this concept is not without problems is another matter.
Uneven development is at the heart of the matter: if capitalism is just here and there, but not everywhere, we must wait until it is everywhere to fight against it.
